element.name: A Walk in the Park by redflame1, Multi-cache (2/1)
element.description: A pleasant tour of Shanganagh Park - Shankill's first cache. Enjoy!
element.long-description:
The Park
Shanganagh Park in Shankill was formerly known as Tyrell's land, and is about 42 hectares in extent. The major portion, consisting of about 40 hectares, was acquired specifically for public open space in 1982.
The main railway divides Shanganagh Park in half. A pedestrian bridge was installed jointly by Dun Laoghaire Rathdown County Council and larnrod Eireann in 1995-1996 to improve access.
The Park provides a range of recreational activities including playing pitches, an adventure style playground, a Trim Trail, woodland and coastal walks.
The public open space at Quinn's Road is home to Shankill Tennis Club and Shankill Bowling Club.
The Park is open year round from dawn until dusk.
For more information on Shanganagh Park please visit the Dun Laoighre Rathdown County Council website at: www.dlrcoco.ie/parks
Public Transport: Shankill DART Station is apx 10 - 12 min walk from the park main entrance. Dublin Bus No. 45 travels from Merrion Square to Bray and has a stop at the park entrance.
The Cache
To find the cache you will need to visit a number of locations, all of which are inside Shanganagh Park.
Stage One: N53° 13.322, W006° 07.273 At this location, you should take a look at the Map on the Park Information Board to familiarise yourself with the park layout. Nearby, how many seagulls can the dolphin see? Call this A.
Stage Two: N53° 13.474, W006° 06.971 At Fitness Step 13 on the Trim Trail, how many rungs do you count? Call this B.
Stage Three: N53° 13.656, W006° 06.875 How many net supporting poles surround the Home Plate at the Baseball Field? Call this C.
Stage Four: N53° 13.701, W006° 06.736 Point 4 on the notice board at the Dog Park defines an adult as D years or older.
Stage Five: N53° 13.818, W006° 06.543 At the Quinn’s Road entrance there is a sign – the year mentioned on the second line of the first paragraph is EFGH.
You now have all the clues you need to find the cache, which is at:
N 53° [E] [square root of F] . [H] [F-G] [C] W 6° [C-G] [D-10] . [square root of (D+F)] [A squared] [B-F]
Additional Waypoints AA271WB - Stage 1 N 53° 13.322 W 006° 07.273
BB271WB - Stage 2 N 53° 13.474 W 006° 06.971
CC271WB - Stage 3 N 53° 13.656 W 006° 06.875
DD271WB - Stage 4 N 53° 13.701 W 006° 06.736
EE271WB - Stage 5 N 53° 13.818 W 006° 06.543
FF271WB - Shanganagh Park Car Park N 53° 13.342 W 006° 07.063

ul.li:
2010-05-30T19:00:00Z : Found it by Spark_ie
Had an enjoyable cycle around this lovely park in the sunshine today. Got all the numbers no problems, and had to search for a while to find the cache. Got there in the end! Class logbook [:)] TFTC, Spark_ie

2010-05-10T19:00:00Z : Found it by theswerve
Got info at stages ok...went to calculated final coords...redone maths...got same result?????...clue made no sense but then i thought and it suddenly made sense....cache in hand in seconds...log book good allright....TFTC...

2010-05-02T19:00:00Z : Found it by didi2206
I agree...What a lovely log book! and in our local park too! Nora the mutts and I found it during one of our regular rambles but didn't bring anything nice to drop in- will sort that out soon! TFTgorgeousC

2010-04-28T19:00:00Z : Found it by kaputing
This is a new benchmarks for logbook quality - wow! Stunning and a massive amount of work. Thanks so much. Took us two goes to get this. Had the coords right but just didn't believe them (or at least assumed the cache would be somewhere else). Found a hoard of golf balls but no cache. Eventually decided to trust the coords and sure enough it was pretty much there. Got a quick email from Windsockers that put us right too. Again thanks enjoyed this one.

2010-04-25T19:00:00Z : Found it by daraconn
The logbook is lovely! Thanks for putting thought and care into decorating the logbook - it made the cache memorable and a little bit special, and made me smile when I opened it!
This cache is very "local" for me. Although I live in Sandyford now, I grew up in Shankill and often go for walks with my dog through Shanganagh Park and down onto the beach when I'm in the area to visit my dad. So I was delighted to see a cache published there. Yesterday (Saturday) morning my wife and I visited the first two stages before we ran out of time and had to leave. Then this afternoon on the way back from the Sugarloaf I came back to finish this cache. Nice tour of the park, and straight to the final co-ordinates. At first I couldn't believe the co-ordinates were right, but a little poking around revealed a nicely hidden cache. Back to the car just as it started to rain heavily; very nice timing. Thanks for an enjoyable caching experience!

wpt.name: GC271WB
wpt.desc: A Walk in the Park by redflame1, Multi-cache (2/1)
